Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Recruitment, Hiring Practices, and Wage Gaps

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1333226
PI: Christy Glass
Co-PI: Elizabeth Kiester
Utah State University

Scholars have identified a phenomenon known as the motherhood wage penalty with research demonstrating that women with children face wage discrepancies beyond those associated with being female. Experimental research has allowed scholars to document respondents' negative assessments of mothers' work-related aptitude relative to childless women and men. However, the ways in which the policy environment shapes employer behavior, and the correlation between what employers do and what they say they do in actual work environments, has yet to be examined. The primary research question of this project is "how do employer recruitment and hiring practices shape mothers' access to jobs?" The investigators hypothesize that employers' recruitment and hiring practices can create barriers to mothers' employment through employer bias and discrimination. This project employs a novel mixed-methods approach, combining a multi-state audit study with qualitative employer interviews. First, the audit study provides data for a quantitative analysis predicting the likelihood of a mother receiving a callback for an interview. Second, qualitative interviews allow employers to describe and explain in depth their policies and practices that lead to the outcomes measured in the audit study. The project concludes by comparing observations from the audit study with employer responses. This research fills a gap in the existing literature by addressing this mechanism that may not only be creating barriers to employment but contributing to the motherhood wage penalty as well. This question comes at an important time when legal precedence has long since been established to prevent discrimination yet reports continue to reveal discriminatory practices and outcomes.

Broader Impacts: This project tests whether, to what degree and to what effect mothers are a target of employer discrimination. In addition to contributing to theory and research in the fields of gender, work and organizations, these findings will potentially influence employer practices, anti-discrimination laws and employment policies. Additionally, this project adds a comparative element that examines effects of both state- level policies and firm-level characteristics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While gender inequity in wages is often discussed in the media and referenced by politicians, the motherhood wage penalty receives substantially less attention. This distinct wage penalty suggests that women with children suffer a wage penalty separate from women without children. In addition, there is an employment gap between mothers and non-mothers indicating that mothers are less likely to be employed. While some argue that this is a matter of choice, I contend that mothers may face unique barriers that deny them access to the labor market. I tested this theory in two ways and in two states: California and Utah. First, I sent two applications to 240 companies in each state (960 applications in total); both applicants were women but one indicated that she was a mother through the use of email addresses and work-related activities. I then kept track of which applicants received follow-up emails or phone calls. If employers were biased and discriminated against mothers, I would expect that the “mother” candidate would receive less follow-up contacts. The second way I investigated this issue was by directly speaking with hiring managers at 27 of the companies that I applied to. I asked them questions regarding their ideal worker, gender preferences, and the relevance of family responsibilities in their hiring decisions.

Findings from both studies indicate that employers’ assumptions about mothers create a bias against them when they are being considered for employment. In the first study, I found that even with incredibly subtle indicators of motherhood, strong trends support my assumption that motherhood will negatively impact the likelihood of a woman receiving a callback. Additionally, by conducting this study in two different states, I was able to evaluate the salience of motherhood across different cultural settings. Mothers in Utah faced a more substantial disadvantage then mothers in California.

In the second study, I found that employers often define their ideal worker through skills including competence, dedication, and availability. Unfortunately, these criteria often devalue mothers as employees, as they are often thought to be less competent, less dedicated, and less flexible with their time due to childcare responsibilities.  While hiring managers in both states had ideal expectations regarding the competence and availability of their applicants the cultural differences in Utah appeared to make it more difficult for mothers to balance work and family responsibilities. Utah employers seem to understand that there was a cultural expectation for flexibility, making motherhood more salient, effectively subjecting mothers to employer bias if they are then assumed to be less flexible and available. Employers in California shaped their expectations regarding flexibility more in a different way as their state provided more substantial work-family policies which decreased the salience of motherhood in their hiring decisions.

Intellectual Merit

 This project expands our understanding of motherhood penalties by analyzing employers’ hiring practices – key mechanisms that may create barriers to the labor market through screening processes designed to alert employers to parental status. Analysis of these employment practices advances the field in three ways. First, this research identifies mechanisms that contribute to motherhood penalties at a societal level. Existing research has primarily focused on wage gaps because these can be measured with aggregate data. However, recruitment and hiring processes, which take place at the level of the firm, are harder to measure empirically.
